channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 1 September
item.description: CovidCard trials will go ahead despite a backer pulling out, an update on case numbers, schools struggling with funds, negative test results for MIQ workers and more - today's Covid-19 wrap.

item.title: Widow says assisted death would have been a kinder option
item.description: A woman whose terminally-ill husband chose suicide over a prolonged painful death is urging New Zealanders to allow people the option to die with dignity.

item.title: Winter Energy Payment to end: 'Their income is going to fall off a cliff'
item.description: Some beneficiaries are set to lose more than $60 from their weekly pay next month, despite record demand for food banks and emergency assistance.

item.title: Green School at centre of $12m funding debacle struggling with backlash
item.description: Green School chief executive Chris Edwards says the school applied for the funding in good faith. It's been "misrepresented", its reputation tarnished and turned into a political football, he says.

item.title: Bureaucracy hampering CovidCard development, innovator Ian Taylor says
item.description: Checkpoint - A trial of the CovidCard will still go ahead, despite businessman Sam Morgan and his team pulling out, but innovator Ian Taylor is urging Morgan not to walk away.

item.title: Aoraki/Mt Cook blaze: 'The fire's sitting there under a cover of snow'
item.description: It could take months to fully extinguish a scrub fire in the Mackenzie District, despite rain and snow overnight, but the area is safe to return to, firefighters say.

item.title: EQC not equipped for future quake repair oversight - CEO
item.description: Checkpoint - The Earthquake Commission chief executive says the agency does not have the capability to lead any future repair programme.

item.title: Covid-19 update: 14 new cases, five in the community
item.description: The Ministry of Health has revealed 14 new cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand.

item.title: Holiday of fire and ice for Nelson family
item.description: A Nelson family on a South Island road trip have experienced wildfire and blizzard in the same place within days.

item.title: Kiwibank and TSB online services impacted
item.description: Both banks have had some of their services go offline today due to network issues. It is not clear if this is connected to cyber attacks against New Zealand institutions in the past week.

item.title: Mt Cook fire update from Civil Defence minister and Mackenzie District mayor
item.description: Property owners who had cleared away vegetation fared better in the large Mackenzie Country fire than those who had not, the region's mayor says.

item.title: Christchurch mosque shooter designated as a terrorist entity
item.description: The Christchurch mosque shooter has been designated as a terrorist entity by the PM, who says it's an "important demonstration" of NZ's "condemnation of terrorism and violent extremism".

item.title: Volunteer firefighter association CEO stood down while harassment claims investigated
item.description: The chief executive of the United Fire Brigades' Association, Bill Butzbach, has been stood down while allegations of bullying and harassment are investigated.

item.title: Rotorua man rents motels to house homeless during pandemic
item.description: A Rotorua man's charitable trust is renting motels to house people after the Covid-19 pandemic forced him to shut his shelters for the homeless.

item.title: No quarantine or managed isolation staff have tested positive - Woods
item.description: The minister in charge of managed isolation facilities Megan Woods says none of the staff there have tested positive, with 97 percent tested.

item.title: Fairness concerns over isolation escapees' sentences
item.description: Sentences for isolation escapees should take circumstances into account, a law academic says, after a woman was jailed for two weeks for escaping with her children to attend their father's tangi.

item.title: Kai Ika project donating fish to whƒÅnau struggles with demand
item.description: A not-for-profit which donates fish parts from commercial fishers to families in need has called for help to meet the growing demand in Auckland.

item.title: NZX attacks embarrassing and unusual, head of TUANZ says
item.description: The head of the Telecommunications Users Association of New Zealand says the attacks on the NZX are highly unusual and serve as a good reminder for corporates to make sure their defences are up.
